content.description: The table below shows the values of different elasticities of demand for good J at the market equilibrium price. Price elasticity (absolute value) <math alttext="0.75" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.75</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Cross-price elasticity with respect to good X <math alttext="0.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Cross-price elasticity with respect to good Y <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Cross-price elasticity with respect to good Z <math alttext="negative 2.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> Income elasticity <math alttext="negative 0.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.5</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Which of the following would result in the greatest rightward shift of the demand curve for good J?

choices.label: A <math alttext="50 percent" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> decrease in the price of good J.
A <math alttext="20 percent" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> increase in the price of good X.
A <math alttext="10 percent" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> increase in the price of good Y.
A <math alttext="10 percent" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>10%</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increase in the price of good Z.
A <math alttext="10 percent" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> decrease in income.

content.answer: A <math alttext="10 percent" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> increase in the price of good Y.

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Interpret a specific economic outcome using quantitative data or calculations.
